entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 26 at 8:32AM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA
entry.summary:
At 832 AM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm capable of producing funnel clouds 8 miles northwest of Vancleave, or 14 miles north of St. Martin, moving north at 20 mph.
HAZARD...Funnel clouds and winds in excess of 40 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...If a funnel cloud briefly touches down, minor damage to outdoor objects is possible. Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
Locations impacted include... Biloxi, Ocean Springs, St. Martin, D'iberville, Latimer, Gulf Hills, Gulf Park Estates, and Vancleave.
This includes the following Interstates... Interstate 10 in Mississippi between mile markers 43 and 57. Interstate 110 in Mississippi between mile markers 1 and 4.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Harrison; Northern Jackson; Southern Harrison; Southern Jackson

cap:parameter.value: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM WILL IMPACT PORTIONS OF NORTHEASTERN HARRISON AND WESTERN JACKSON COUNTIES THROUGH 915 AM CDT

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued October 26 at 7:46AM CDT until October 26 at 11:00AM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA
entry.summary:
FFWLIX
The National Weather Service in New Orleans has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Eastern Amite County in southern Mississippi... Pike County in southern Mississippi... Northwestern Walthall County in southern Mississippi...
* Until 1100 AM CDT.
* At 746 AM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Mccomb, Magnolia, Summit, Salem and Mccomb Airport.
This includes the following Interstate... Interstate 55 in Mississippi between mile markers 10 and 24.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Amite, MS; Pike, MS; Walthall, MS

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 26 at 6:20AM CDT by NWS Austin/San Antonio TX
entry.summary: A region of patchy dense fog has developed from Llano County east-southeatward through Travis/Williamson counties and into Fayette county. Fog will reduce visibility to less than a half mile at times this morning within this area. Visibility will improve by mid to late morning. Motorists should drive with caution in fog by slowing down, providing extra space between the vehicle ahead of you, and using the low beams.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Llano; Burnet; Williamson; Travis; Bastrop; Lee; Fayette

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 26 at 5:58AM CDT by NWS Green Bay WI
entry.summary:
Patchy dense fog, with a visibility of 1/4 mile or less, developed across portions of central and northeast Wisconsin this morning. Some locations experiencing dense fog shortly before sunrise include: Tomahawk, Antigo, Clintonville and Shawano.
If you have travel plans for the morning commute, slow down and use your low beam headlights if you encounter dense fog. Also allow extra time to reach your destination as the commute may be slower than normal. The dense fog should burn off by 10 am.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Oneida; Forest; Lincoln; Langlade; Menominee; Marathon; Shawano; Portage; Waupaca

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 26 at 6:40AM EDT by NWS Buffalo NY
entry.summary:
Webcams and satellite imagery continue to indicate areas of fog across the Southern Tier, especially in the valleys, including portions of Interstate 86 and Route 219. Some of this fog is locally dense in spots, with visibilities down to a quarter of a mile or less at times.
If you will be traveling this morning, be sure to slow down and be prepared for rapid changes in visibility. The fog is expected to dissipate by 10 AM.

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued October 26 at 5:38AM CDT until October 26 at 10:00PM CDT by NWS Mobile AL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 4 to 6 feet in the surf zone. For the High Rip Current Risk, dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...In Alabama, Mobile Coastal and Baldwin Coastal Counties. In Florida, Escambia Coastal, Santa Rosa Coastal and Okaloosa Coastal Counties.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 10 PM CDT Sunday. For the High Rip Current Risk, through Monday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...High surf combined with high tide each night may result in overwash and minor inundation of portions of Dauphin Island and Fort Pickens.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Mobile Coastal; Baldwin Coastal; Escambia Coastal; Santa Rosa Coastal; Okaloosa Coastal

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 26 at 2:33AM PDT until October 27 at 3:00AM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A moderate to long period northwesterly swell will result in breaking waves of 15 to 20 feet, with the highest waves up to 25 feet in favored locations, and an increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents.
* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern Monterey Bay and Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast Counties.
* WHEN...Through late Sunday night.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should always swim near a lifeguard.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE TONIGHT

* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 20 to 28 feet with a high risk of sneaker waves during any lulls in high surf.
* WHERE...All beaches and surf of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.
* WHEN...Until 8 PM PDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Large breaking waves will create hazardous conditions along and within the surf zone, and could inundate beaches and low lying shorelines. Waves could wash over rocks and jetties, beach erosion is possible, and exposed infrastructure may be damaged.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Waves are likely most dangerous during the run up to high tide. A period of warning level breaking wave heights up to 30 ft are possible into this evening.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM PDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 25 at 8:51PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Volusia and Lake Counties.
.The St Johns River at Astor remains within Minor Flood Stage due to past rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The river is forecast to remain within Minor Flood Stage, with levels slowly falling through the weekend, but rising again slightly early next week as higher tides and a wind shift occurs.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Minor flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Sunday morning at 1100 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 2.8 feet, Docks and boat ramps covered at South Moon Fish Camp and approaching sea wall at Blair's Jungle Den. Water approaching sites closest to the river at Fish Tales RV Resort and Astor Landing Campground. Portion of Clair Street covered by river water south of the Butler Boat Ramp. Docks underwater at the Astor Bridge Marina and along Riveredge Drive. Portions of Fox Road are covered with water nearest to the river. Acorn, Hazelnut and Redbud roads are underwater with yards inundated.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM EDT Saturday the stage was 2.7 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 PM EDT Saturday was 2.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 2.6 feet late this weekend before rising back to 2.8 feet into the middle of next week. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 25 at 12:45PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
An active weather pattern returns on Tuesday through the end of the week as multiple, potentially impactful, weather systems push into the panhandle.
These storms will bring strong winds, elevated seas, and heavy rain to areas along the coast and inner channel communities. Forecast confidence is increasing that the strongest of these systems will push into the panhandle by Wednesday night, with multiple rounds of strong winds and heavy rain continuing through Friday.
Mariners along the coast should anticipate multiple rounds of gale force winds of 34kts or greater to develop Wednesday night and continue through Friday, with stronger gusts likely.
Stay tuned to the latest forecast, please visit weather.gov/juneau
entry.cap:areaDesc: City and Borough of Yakutat; Municipality of Skagway; Haines Borough and Klukwan; Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Sitka; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; City of Hyder; Annette Island
